intro: Alyssum dimorphosepalum, commonly known as the two-sepal alyssum, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10–30 centimeters and features hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are usually white or pale pink, and it blooms from late spring to early summer. Alyssum dimorphosepalum is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
